Black Student Service Center Records
New York University. Black Student Service Center
RG.39.212
3 Linear Feet in 2 record cartons and one oversize flat box
1979-2019 The Black Student Service Center (BSSC) at New York University was established in 1973 "to enrich the cultural, social, and educational experiences of the Black student." This collection contains the organization's records and photographs from BSSC special events. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Content Description
This collection contains organizational records from the Black Student Service Center at New York University. Included are correspondence, bylaws and constitutions, committee minutes, expense receipts and budgets, membership lists, publicity materials, and event photographs.
Arrangement
Organizational records are arranged chronologically, followed by photographs of special events.
Biographical / Historical
The Black Student Service Center (BSSC) at New York University (NYU) was established in 1973 "to enrich the cultural, social, and educational experiences of the Black student." A representative committee of undergraduate students of color from NYU's University Heights and Washington Square campuses submitted their proposal to NYU Chancellor Eleazer Bromberg via Roscoe C. Brown, Jr., director of NYU's Institute of Afro-American Affairs.
The BSSC constitution states its purpose: "to provide concerned students with facilities to promote educational, political, cultural, social, and career-oriented exchange on campus."
The BSSC sponsored many annual events at NYU, including Black History Month talks, Kwanzaa celebrations, jazz concerts, career days, education forums, fashion shows, and an annual awards dinner.
In 1985 the BSSC received the Chancellor's Service Award for Programming at NYU.
Conditions Governing Access
Material pertaining to individual student records may be restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). Please contact the Archives with specific questions regarding access to such records.
Conditions Governing Use
Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the creator are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from New York University Archives, (212) 998-2646, university-archives@nyu.edu.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Transferred from Loeb Student Center operations in 1997.
Preferred Citation

Processing Information
Materials were placed in acid-free folders and boxes. Original folder label information, when available, was retained. In January 2020 the call number for this collection was changed from RG 12.10 to RG 39.212.
